questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which command needs to be placed on the box where the code is missing to output the value of page_id in the Python 3.7 script?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

cat test.py
----
items={'items':[{'a':'b','page_id':'d'}]}

print (items)
print (items.get('items'))
print (items.get('items')[0].get('page_id'))
print (items.get('items').get('page_id'))
--
$ python test.py
{'items': [{'a': 'b', 'page_id': 'd'}]}
[{'a': 'b', 'page_id': 'd'}]
d
Traceback (most recent call last):
 File "test.py", line 9, in <module>
 print (items.get('items').get('page_id'))
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'get'
B is correct because the .get()

comments.content: B is missing the [0] to access the first element in the list.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct. 'items' is an array within which elements can only be references by it's numerical index followed by the 'page_id' dictionary key.

Selected Answer: D
I will go for D.
function is already assigned to variable "items"
Hence no need for get

Selected Answer: A
A is the only option as only A has [0] to get list element

with no special chars:

A. print(items.get("items")[0].get("page_id"))
B. print(items.get("items").get("page_id"))
C. print(items["items"]["page_id"].keys())
D. print(items["items"]["page_id"])
from the next link. Should be option B. auth=(amp_client_id, amp_api_key)) it uses amp_api_key https://community.cisco.com/t5/endpoint-security/api-query-with-an-exact-match/td-p/4105767
The confusion is caused by this line:"...your api_key was 'atest' ". That value looks more like a password than an API key.
Is itBasic Authentication if its using an APi key? That's what i dont understand about this question.

comments.content:
yes, basic is a kind of encryptation for authenticacion along with bearer and digest, which are the most common for cisco 

https://developer.mozilla.org/es/docs/Web/HTTP/Authentication
Basic authentication with Base64 is encoding and not encryption

discussion.content:
B is the correct.
Check the https example.
First client ID then token

comments.content: I mean first the client ID and then the key

discussion.content:
B is the correct, although no HTTPBasicAuth as been defined for the auth type.
Because of this, I think there's no absolute correct answer.

comments.content:
Using auth=(x,y) is the shorthand for auth=HTTPBasicAuth(x,y)
https://requests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/authentication/

discussion.content: B is the correct

The answer is B.
https://api-docs.amp.cisco.com/api_resources?api_host=api.amp.cisco.com&api_version=v1 

All API requests must use HTTP Basic Auth.
Generating Client ID and API Key:

 Log in to your AMP for Endpoints Console.
 Go to Accounts > API Credentials.
 Click New API Credential to generate an API Key and Client ID.

Once you have the API client ID and API key, you can make the API calls as follows:

https://<your_client_id>:<your_api_key>@<api_endpoint>/<api_version>/<resource>

Alternatively you can use Basic HTTP Authentication. Base 64 encode the string ":", and send that prefixed with the string "Basic" as the authorization header. For instance, if your client_id was 1234, and your api_key was "atest", then it would be base64 encoded to "MTIzNDphdGVzdA==", and your header would be:

Authorization: Basic MTIzNDphdGVzdA==

B is the only one that is using basic auth(amp_client_id, amp_api_key) on the header
should be B
Which is the right answer?

comments.content: Option D has a wrong parameter called amp_login_password where have to be amp_api_key according to URL to make API calls: "https://<your_client_id>:<your_api_key>@<api_endpoint>. Correct answer is B

discussion.content: D might be the correct choice here: https://developer.cisco.com/docs/pyats/#!introduction/cisco-pyats-network-test--automation-solution

Pro tip on these questions that have jacked-up formatting with the ג€ special chars.
Go to DevTools (Press F12 in Chrome), go to the Console tab, and run this:
document.body.innerHTML = document.body.innerHTML.replace(/ג€/g, "'")
That will replace all of the junk chars on your current page with the proper single quotes.
Sad that we pay hundreds for this site, and they can't render text properly.

Selected Answer: D
D
Very easy.
Format is authorization:Bearer token

comments.content:
A says "Authentication"
D says "Authorization"

Authorization is always the correct syntax within the header

discussion.content: What is the difference between A and D?
header = {"Authorization": "Bearer XYzdfsdfsd234sad4"}

Selected Answer: D
It is D.
Why? - OAuth 2.0 uses Bearer Authentication:
Authorization: Bearer <Bearer Token>
It's D

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A developer creates a Python script that queries Cisco Webex. When the script is executed, a 401 code is returned. After troubleshooting, the developer discovers that the service is missing privileges. Which change to the header in line 4 of the script results in the code 200?

DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the HTTP methods from the left onto their generally accepted corresponding create, read, update, and delete operations on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Create POST
Read GET
Update PATCH / PUT
Delete DELETE

Delete – Delete
GET – Read
Patch – Update
Post- Create
Put – replace

comments.content:
PUT -> Modifies or Create entire resource (REPLACE)
PATCH -> Modifies partially without modifying the entire resource(UPDATE)

discussion.content: Yes, the order is POST, GET, PUT , PATCH, DELETE. Source netacad and book Devasc have the same order
{POST, GET, PATCH, PUT, DELETE}

Does order matter? 
Update - PATCH
Update - PUT

from elsewhere on the web

get
base_url
networks
network _id
clients
api_key
application/json
params
timespan
432000

network_id and 43200 are inverted, the rest is good. There are also several errors: 
- between item 4 and item 5 there should a + not a ,
- api_key should be "Bearer xxxxxx" and not just the token

oh well anyway

432000

network_id and 43200 are inverted.

Check the API and the code generated for python, the answer is there:

https://developer.cisco.com/meraki/api-v1/#!get-network-clients
I agree too
6 & 7 are mixed up i believe. not sure of others.
